1.verse: Like a stream is the king's heart in the hand of the LORD; wherever it pleases him, he directs it.

2.verse: All the ways of a man may be right in his own eyes, but it is the LORD who proves hearts.

3.verse: To do what is right and just is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.

4.verse: Haughty eyes and a proud heart - the tillage of the wicked is sin.

5.verse: The plans of the diligent are sure of profit, but all rash haste leads certainly to poverty.

6.verse: He who makes a fortune by a lying tongue is chasing a bubble over deadly snares.

7.verse: The oppression of the wicked will sweep them away, because they refuse to do what is right.

8.verse: The way of the culprit is crooked, but the conduct of the innocent is right.

9.verse: It is better to dwell in a corner of the housetop than in a roomy house with a quarrelsome woman.

10.verse: The soul of the wicked man desires evil; his neighbor finds no pity in his eyes.

11.verse: When the arrogant man is punished, the simple are the wiser; when the wise man is instructed, he gains knowledge.

12.verse: The just man appraises the house of the wicked: there is one who brings down the wicked to ruin.

13.verse: He who shuts his ear to the cry of the poor will himself also call and not be heard.

14.verse: A secret gift allays anger, and a concealed present, violent wrath.

15.verse: To practice justice is a joy for the just, but terror for evildoers.

16.verse: The man who strays from the way of good sense will abide in the assembly of the shades.

17.verse: He who loves pleasure will suffer want; he who loves wine and perfume will not be rich.

18.verse: The wicked man serves as ransom for the just, and the faithless man for the righteous.

19.verse: It is better to dwell in a wilderness than with a quarrelsome and vexatious wife.

20.verse: Precious treasure remains in the house of the wise, but the fool consumes it.

21.verse: He who pursues justice and kindness will find life and honor.

22.verse: The wise man storms a city of the mighty, and overthrows the stronghold in which it trusts.

23.verse: He who guards his mouth and his tongue keeps himself from trouble.

24.verse: Arrogant is the name for the man of overbearing pride who acts with scornful effrontery.

25.verse: The sluggard's propensity slays him, for his hands refuse to work.

26.verse: Some are consumed with avarice all the day, but the just man gives unsparingly.

27.verse: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination, the more so when they offer it with a bad intention.

28.verse: The false witness will perish, but he who listens will finally have his say.

29.verse: The wicked man is brazenfaced, but the upright man pays heed to his ways.

30.verse: There is no wisdom, no understanding, no counsel, against the LORD.

31.verse: The horse is equipped for the day of battle, but victory is the LORD'S.

annotations.1: [3] External rites or sacrifices do not please God unless accompanied by internal worship and right moral conduct; cf Proverb 15:8; 21:27; Isaiah 1:11-15; Amos 5:22; Malachi 1:12.
annotations.2: [16] Assembly of the shades: cf note on Job 26:5
annotations.3: [18] Wicked . . . ransom for the just: exemplified in the history of God's chosen people whom he ransomed from Egypt at the cost of the life of Pharaoh and his army ( Exodus 14:23-31), and from Babylon by giving to Cyrus, the Persian conqueror, Egypt, Ethiopia and Seba, the richest lands of the world ( Isaiah 43:1-3)

1.verse: The words of Lemuel, king of Massa. The advice which his mother gave him:

2.verse: What, my son, my first-born! what, O son of my womb; what, O son of my vows!

3.verse: Give not your vigor to women, nor your strength to those who ruin kings.

4.verse: It is not for kings, O Lemuel, not for kings to drink wine; strong drink is not for princes!

5.verse: Lest in drinking they forget what the law decrees, and violate the rights of all who are in need.

6.verse: Give strong drink to one who is perishing, and wine to the sorely depressed;

7.verse: When they drink, they will forget their misery, and think no more of their burdens.

8.verse: Open your mouth in behalf of the dumb, and for the rights of the destitute;

9.verse: Open your mouth, decree what is just, defend the needy and the poor!

10.verse: When one finds a worthy wife, her value is far beyond pearls.

11.verse: Her husband, entrusting his heart to her, has an unfailing prize.

12.verse: She brings him good, and not evil, all the days of her life.

13.verse: She obtains wool and flax and makes cloth with skillful hands.

14.verse: Like merchant ships, she secures her provisions from afar.

15.verse: She rises while it is still night, and distributes food to her household.

16.verse: She picks out a field to purchase; out of her earnings she plants a vineyard.

17.verse: She is girt about with strength, and sturdy are her arms.

18.verse: She enjoys the success of her dealings; at night her lamp is undimmed.

19.verse: She puts her hands to the distaff, and her fingers ply the spindle.

20.verse: She reaches out her hands to the poor, and extends her arms to the needy.

21.verse: She fears not the snow for her household; all her charges are doubly clothed.

22.verse: She makes her own coverlets; fine linen and purple are her clothing.

23.verse: Her husband is prominent at the city gates as he sits with the elders of the land.

24.verse: She makes garments and sells them, and stocks the merchants with belts.

25.verse: She is clothed with strength and dignity, and she laughs at the days to come.

26.verse: She opens her mouth in wisdom, and on her tongue is kindly counsel.

27.verse: She watches the conduct of her household, and eats not her food in idleness.

28.verse: Her children rise up and praise her; her husband, too, extols her:

29.verse: "Many are the women of proven worth, but you have excelled them all."

30.verse: Charm is deceptive and beauty fleeting; the woman who fears the LORD is to be praised.

31.verse: Give her a reward of her labors, and let her works praise her at the city gates.

annotations.1: [12] Good, and not evil: i.e., prosperity, not adversity.
annotations.2: [14] Merchant: literally, "Canaanite" (cf Proverb 31:24), probably because the merchant class had been composed chiefly of Canaanites
annotations.3: [18] Her lamp is undimmed: indicates abundance of productive work and its accompanying prosperity; cf Proverb 20:20; Job 18:6
annotations.4: [25] Laughs at the days to come: anticipates the future with gladness free from anxiety
annotations.5: [30] The true charm of the ideal wife is her religious spirit, for she fears the LORD; cf note on Proverb 1:7

1.verse: My son, if you receive my words and treasure my commands,

2.verse: Turning your ear to wisdom, inclining your heart to understanding;

3.verse: Yes, if you call to intelligence, and to understanding raise your voice;

4.verse: If you seek her like silver, and like hidden treasures search her out:

5.verse: Then will you understand the fear of the LORD; the knowledge of God you will find;

6.verse: For the LORD gives wisdom, from his mouth come knowledge and understanding;

7.verse: He has counsel in store for the upright, he is the shield of those who walk honestly,

8.verse: Guarding the paths of justice, protecting the way of his pious ones.

9.verse: Then you will understand rectitude and justice, honesty, every good path;

10.verse: For wisdom will enter your heart, knowledge will please your soul,

11.verse: Discretion will watch over you, understanding will guard you;

12.verse: Saving you from the way of evil men, from men of perverse speech,

13.verse: Who leave the straight paths to walk in the way of darkness,

14.verse: Who delight in doing evil, rejoice in perversity;

15.verse: Whose ways are crooked, and devious their paths;

16.verse: Saving you from the wife of another, from the adulteress with her smooth words,

17.verse: Who forsakes the companion of her youth and forgets the pact with her God;

18.verse: For her path sinks down to death, and her footsteps lead to the shades;

19.verse: None who enter thereon come back again, or gain the paths of life.

20.verse: Thus you may walk in the way of good men, and keep to the paths of the just.

21.verse: For the upright will dwell in the land, the honest will remain in it;

22.verse: But the wicked will be cut off from the land, the faithless will be rooted out of it.

annotations.1: [Chapters 2-7] These chapters form an ordered discourse in seven "columns" of twenty-two verses each. Chapter 2 introduces the four topics about which the sage instructs his pupil: the service of God ( Proverb 3:1-12, 25-34) the search for wisdom ( Proverb 3:13-24, 35; 4:1-9), the avoidance of evil companions among men ( Proverb 4:10-27; 5:21-23), and among women ( 5:1-20; 6:20- 7:27). The last topic is treated at a length equal to the first three because the discourse is meant especially for youths (cf Proverb 1:4)
annotations.2: [1-22] The search for wisdom ( Proverb 2:1-4) leads to the protection of God ( Proverb 2:5-8) and of wisdom herself ( Proverb 2:9-11; cf Proverb 1:20-33) and to deliverance from evil men ( Proverb 2:12-15) and evil women ( Proverb 2:16-19), and so to lasting happiness ( Proverb 2:20-22).
annotations.3: [2-3] Wisdom, understanding, intelligence: various names or aspects of the same gift

1.verse: He who loves correction loves knowledge, but he who hates reproof is stupid.

2.verse: The good man wins favor from the LORD, but the schemer is condemned by him.

3.verse: No man is built up by wickedness, but the root of the just will never be disturbed.

4.verse: A worthy wife is the crown of her husband, but a disgraceful one is like rot in his bones.

5.verse: The plans of the just are legitimate; the designs of the wicked are deceitful.

6.verse: The words of the wicked are a deadly ambush, but the speech of the upright saves them.

7.verse: The wicked are overthrown and are no more, but the house of the just stands firm.

8.verse: According to his good sense a man is praised, but one with a warped mind is despised.

9.verse: Better a lowly man who supports himself than one of assumed importance who lacks bread.

10.verse: The just man takes care of his beast, but the heart of the wicked is merciless.

11.verse: He who tills his own land has food in plenty, but he who follows idle pursuits is a fool.

12.verse: The stronghold of evil men will be demolished, but the root of the just is enduring.

13.verse: In the sin of his lips the evil man is ensnared, but the just comes free of trouble.

14.verse: From the fruit of his words a man has his fill of good things, and the work of his hands comes back to reward him.

15.verse: The way of the fool seems right in his own eyes, but he who listens to advice is wise.

16.verse: The fool immediately shows his anger, but the shrewd man passes over an insult.

17.verse: He tells the truth who states what he is sure of, but a lying witness speaks deceitfully.

18.verse: The prating of some men is like sword thrusts, but the tongue of the wise is healing.

19.verse: Truthful lips endure forever, the lying tongue, for only a moment.

20.verse: Deceit is in the hands of those who plot evil, but those who counsel peace have joy.

21.verse: No harm befalls the just, but the wicked are overwhelmed with misfortune.

22.verse: Lying lips are an abomination to the LORD, but those who are truthful are his delight.

23.verse: A shrewd man conceals his knowledge, but the hearts of fools gush forth folly.

24.verse: The diligent hand will govern, but the slothful will be enslaved.

25.verse: Anxiety in a man's heart depresses it, but a kindly word makes it glad.

26.verse: The just man surpasses his neighbor, but the way of the wicked leads them astray.

27.verse: The slothful man catches not his prey, but the wealth of the diligent man is great.

28.verse: In the path of justice there is life, but the abominable way leads to death.

1.verse: A good name is more desirable than great riches, and high esteem, than gold and silver.

2.verse: Rich and poor have a common bond: the LORD is the maker of them all.

3.verse: The shrewd man perceives evil and hides, while simpletons continue on and suffer the penalty.

4.verse: The reward of humility and fear of the LORD is riches, honor and life.

5.verse: Thorns and snares are on the path of the crooked; he who would safeguard his life will shun them.

6.verse: Train a boy in the way he should go; even when he is old, he will not swerve from it.

7.verse: The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is the slave of the lender.

8.verse: He who sows iniquity reaps calamity, and the rod destroys his labors.

9.verse: The kindly man will be blessed, for he gives of his sustenance to the poor.

10.verse: Expel the arrogant man and discord goes out; strife and insult cease.

11.verse: The LORD loves the pure of heart; the man of winning speech has the king for his friend.

12.verse: The eyes of the LORD safeguard knowledge, but he defeats the projects of the faithless.

13.verse: The sluggard says, "A lion is outside; in the streets I might be slain."

14.verse: The mouth of the adulteress is a deep pit; he with whom the LORD is angry will fall into it.

15.verse: Folly is close to the heart of a child, but the rod of discipline will drive it far from him.

16.verse: He who oppresses the poor to enrich himself will yield up his gains to the rich as sheer loss.

17.verse: The sayings of the wise: Incline your ear, and hear my words, and apply your heart to my doctrine;

18.verse: For it will be well if you keep them in your bosom, if they all are ready on your lips.

19.verse: That your trust may be in the LORD, I make known to you the words of Amen-em-Ope.

20.verse: Have I not written for you the "Thirty," with counsels and knowledge,

21.verse: To teach you truly how to give a dependable report to one who sends you?

22.verse: Injure not the poor because they are poor, nor crush the needy at the gate;

23.verse: For the LORD will defend their cause, and will plunder the lives of those who plunder them.

24.verse: Be not friendly with a hotheaded man, nor the companion of a wrathful man,

25.verse: Lest you learn his ways, and get yourself into a snare.

26.verse: Be not one of those who give their hand in pledge, of those who become surety for debts;

27.verse: For if you have not the means to pay, your bed will be taken from under you.

28.verse: Remove not the ancient landmark which your fathers set up.

29.verse: You see a man skilled at his work? He will stand in the presence of kings; he will not stand in the presence of obscure men.

annotations.1: [13] To avoid the effort required for doing good, the sluggard exaggerates the difficulties that must be overcome.
annotations.2: [16] Money gained by exploiting the poor is in turn lost to those who are more wealthy
annotations.3: [ 22:17- 24:22] This collection of proverbs, introduced as sayings of the wise, is given in the more intimate and personal form of an address to a pupil called the son and is arranged in strophes instead of couplets
annotations.4: [ 22:17- 23:35] The maxims warn against: oppression of the poor and defenseless ( Proverb 22:22-23), anger ( Proverb 22:24-25), giving surety for debts ( Proverb 22:26-27), bad manners at a king's table ( Proverb 23:1-2), anxiety for riches ( Proverb 23:4-5), a grudging host ( Proverb 23:6-8), intemperance in food and drink ( Proverb 23:19-21, 29-35), and adultery ( Proverb 23:26-28). They exhort to: careful workmanship ( Proverb 22:29), respect for the rights of orphans ( Proverb 23:10-11), correction of the young ( Proverb 23:13-14), filial piety ( Proverb 23:15-16, 22-25), and fear of the LORD ( Proverb 23:17-18)
annotations.5: [19-20] Amen-em-Ope:an Egyptian scribe to whom is attributed a collection of maxims in Thirty chapters ( Proverb 22:20) composed for the instruction of his children and addressed to a young man who wishes to enter upon a career. The inspired editor of Proverbs does not translate these, but uses their materials in constructing a similar collection of proverbs

1.verse: My son, if you have become surety to your neighbor, given your hand in pledge to another,

2.verse: You have been snared by the utterance of your lips, caught by the words of your mouth;

3.verse: So do this, my son, to free yourself, since you have fallen into your neighbor's power: Go, hurry, stir up your neighbor!

4.verse: Give no sleep to your eyes, nor slumber to your eyelids;

5.verse: Free yourself as a gazelle from the snare, or as a bird from the hand of the fowler.

6.verse: Go to the ant, O sluggard, study her ways and learn wisdom;

7.verse: For though she has no chief, no commander or ruler,

8.verse: She procures her food in the summer, stores up her provisions in the harvest.

9.verse: How long, O sluggard, will you rest? when will you rise from your sleep?

10.verse: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the arms to rest -

11.verse: Then will poverty come upon you like a highway man, and want like an armed man.

12.verse: A scoundrel, a villain, is he who deals in crooked talk.

13.verse: He winks his eyes, shuffles his feet, makes signs with his fingers;

14.verse: He has perversity in his heart, is always plotting evil, sows discord.

15.verse: Therefore suddenly ruin comes upon him; in an instant he is crushed beyond cure.

16.verse: There are six things the LORD hates, yes, seven are an abomination to him;

17.verse: Haughty eyes, a lying tongue, and hands that shed innocent blood;

18.verse: A heart that plots wicked schemes, feet that run swiftly to evil,

19.verse: The false witness who utters lies, and he who sows discord among brothers.

20.verse: Observe, my son, your father's bidding, and reject not your mother's teaching;

21.verse: Keep them fastened over your heart always, put them around your neck;

23.verse: For the bidding is a lamp, and the teaching a light, and a way to life are the reproofs of discipline;

24.verse: To keep you from your neighbor's wife, from the smooth tongue of the adulteress.

25.verse: Lust not in your heart after her beauty, let her not captivate you with her glance!

26.verse: For the price of a loose woman may be scarcely a loaf of bread, But if she is married, she is a trap for your precious life.

27.verse: Can a man take fire to his bosom, and his garments not burned?

28.verse: Or can a man walk on live coals, and his feet not be scorched?

29.verse: So with him who goes in to his neighbor's wife - none who touches her shall go unpunished.

30.verse: Men despise not the thief if he steals to satisfy his appetite when he is hungry;

31.verse: Yet if he be caught he must pay back sevenfold; all the wealth of his house he may yield up.

32.verse: But he who commits adultery is a fool; he who would destroy himself does it.

33.verse: A degrading beating will he get, and his disgrace will not be wiped away;

34.verse: For vindictive is the husband's wrath, he will have no pity on the day of vengeance;

35.verse: He will not consider any restitution, nor be satisfied with the greatest gifts.

annotations.1: [1-19] These verses interrupt the discourse of chapters Proverb 6:2-7, which should be read apart from them; they contain four shorter proverbs akin to those in Prov 30
annotations.2: [1] Given your hand in pledge: literally, "struck your hands"; this was probably the legal method for closing a contract.
annotations.3: [10] This verse may be regarded as the sluggard's reply or as a continuation of the remonstrance
annotations.4: [16-19] The seven vices symbolized for the most part by bodily organs are pride, lying, murder, intrigue, readiness to do evil, false witness, and the stirring up of discord
annotations.5: [ 6:20- 7:27] Parental training and the love of wisdom are an invaluable and constant help for the young ( Proverb 6:20-23; 7:1-4). They are the best defense against adultery ( Proverb 6:24; 7:5, 24-25), which involves the guilty in many dangers and punishments ( Proverb 6:26-35; 7:6-27). Cf Proverb 5:1-20
annotations.6: [26] Some interpret the verse in a progressive sense, i.e., to satisfy the increasing demands of a courtesan a man is reduced to poverty; if the woman is married, even his very life is endangered

1.verse: A wise son loves correction, but the senseless one heeds no rebuke.

2.verse: From the fruit of his words a man eats good things, but the treacherous one craves violence.

3.verse: He who guards his mouth protects his life; to open wide one's lips brings downfall.

4.verse: The soul of the sluggard craves in vain, but the diligent soul is amply satisfied.

5.verse: Anything deceitful the just man hates, but the wicked brings shame and disgrace.

6.verse: Virtue guards one who walks honestly, but the downfall of the wicked is sin.

7.verse: One man pretends to be rich, yet has nothing; another pretends to be poor, yet has great wealth.

8.verse: A man's riches serve as ransom for his life, but the poor man heeds no rebuke.

9.verse: The light of the just shines gaily, but the lamp of the wicked goes out.

10.verse: The stupid man sows discord by his insolence, but with those who take counsel is wisdom.

11.verse: Wealth quickly gotten dwindles away, but amassed little by little, it grows.

12.verse: Hope deferred makes the heart sick, but a wish fulfilled is a tree of life.

13.verse: He who despises the word must pay for it, but he who reveres the commandment will be rewarded.

14.verse: The teaching of the wise is a fountain of life, that a man may avoid the snares of death.

15.verse: Good sense brings favor, but the way of the faithless is their ruin.

16.verse: The shrewd man does everything with prudence, but the fool peddles folly.

17.verse: A wicked messenger brings on disaster, but a trustworthy envoy is a healing remedy.

18.verse: Poverty and shame befall the man who disregards correction, but he who heeds reproof is honored.

19.verse: Lust indulged starves the soul, but fools hate to turn from evil.

20.verse: Walk with wise men and you will become wise, but the companion of fools will fare badly.

21.verse: Misfortune pursues sinners, but the just shall be recompensed with good.

22.verse: The good man leaves an inheritance to his children's children, but the wealth of the sinner is stored up for the just.

23.verse: A lawsuit devours the tillage of the poor, but some men perish for lack of a law court.

24.verse: He who spares his rod hates his son, but he who loves him takes care to chastise him.

25.verse: When the just man eats, his hunger is appeased; but the belly of the wicked suffers want.

1.verse: Be not emulous of evil men, and desire not to be with them;

2.verse: For their hearts plot violence, and their lips speak of foul play.

3.verse: By wisdom is a house built, by understanding is it made firm;

4.verse: And by knowledge are its rooms filled with every precious and pleasing possession.

5.verse: A wise man is more powerful than a strong man, and a man of knowledge than a man of might;

6.verse: For it is by wise guidance that you wage your war, and the victory is due to a wealth of counselors.

7.verse: For a fool, to be silent is wisdom; not to open his mouth at the gate.

8.verse: He who plots evil doing - men call him an intriguer.

9.verse: Beyond intrigue and folly and sin, it is arrogance that men find abominable.

10.verse: If you remain indifferent in time of adversity, your strength will depart from you.

11.verse: Rescue those who are being dragged to death, and from those tottering to execution withdraw not.

12.verse: If you say, "I know not this man!" does not he who tests hearts perceive it? He who guards your life knows it, and he will repay each one according to his deeds.

13.verse: If you eat honey, my son, because it is good, if virgin honey is sweet to your taste;

14.verse: Such, you must know, is wisdom to your soul. If you find it, you will have a future, and your hope will not be cut off.

15.verse: Lie not in wait against the home of the just man, ravage not his dwelling place;

16.verse: For the just man falls seven times and rises again, but the wicked stumble to ruin.

17.verse: Rejoice not when your enemy falls, and when he stumbles, let not your heart exult,

18.verse: Lest the LORD see it, be displeased with you, and withdraw his wrath from your enemy.

19.verse: Be not provoked with evildoers, nor envious of the wicked;

20.verse: For the evil man has no future, the lamp of the wicked will be put out.

21.verse: My son, fear the LORD and the king; have nothing to do with those who rebel against them;

22.verse: For suddenly arises the destruction they send, and the ruin from either one, who can measure?

23.verse: These also are sayings of the wise: To show partiality in judgment is not good.

24.verse: He who says to the wicked man, "You are just" - men will curse him, people will denounce him;

25.verse: But those who convict the evildoer will fare well, and on them will come the blessing of prosperity.

26.verse: He gives a kiss on the lips who makes an honest reply.

27.verse: Complete your outdoor tasks, and arrange your work in the field; afterward you can establish your house.

28.verse: Be not a witness against your neighbor without just cause, thus committing folly with your lips.

29.verse: Say not, "As he did to me, so will I do to him; I will repay the man according to his deeds."

30.verse: I passed by the field of the sluggard, by the vineyard of the man without sense;

31.verse: And behold! it was all overgrown with thistles; its surface was covered with nettles, and its stone wall broken down.

32.verse: And as I gazed at it, I reflected; I saw and learned the lesson:

33.verse: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the arms to rest -

34.verse: Then will poverty come upon you like a highwayman, and want like an armed man.

annotations.1: [1-22] These verses continue an exhortation to wisdom ( Proverb 24:3-7, 13-14), and against: violence ( Proverb 24:1-2), pride and intrigue ( Proverb 24:8-9), callousness ( Proverb 24:10-12), injustice ( Proverb 24:15-16), joy in the failure of others ( Proverb 24:17-18) or scandal at their success ( Proverb 24:19-20), and rebellion against authority ( Proverb 24:21-22).
annotations.2: [7] At the gate: of the city, where justice was administered and public affairs discussed; see note on Ruth 4:1. Cf also Psalm 69:13; 127:5; Proverb 22:22; 31:23, 31
annotations.3: [10] Indifferent: to those who suffer unjustly
annotations.4: [11] Rescue . . . death: most probably refers to the legal rescue of those unjustly condemned to death
annotations.5: [16] The just man overcomes every misfortune which oppresses him. Seven times: i.e., an indefinite number; cf Matthew 18:21- 22; Luke 17:4
annotations.6: [21-22] One owes obedience to God and to supreme civil authority ( Matthew 22:21; Romans 13:1-3; 1 Peter 2:13-14). The punishments for failure in either duty transcend the limits of private justice
annotations.7: [23-34] This collection of sayings continues in the same vein as the preceding: it instructs in fairness ( Proverb 24:23-26) and preparation for the future ( Proverb 24:27); and warns against vengeance ( Proverb 24:28-29) and slothfulness ( Proverb 24:30-34)
annotations.8: [26] He gives a kiss on the lips: shows himself a true friend
annotations.9: [27] This verse is commonly interpreted as advocating careful and practical preparation for marriage
annotations.10: [29] This verse indicates great progress from the principle of the law of Talion (see note on Exodus 21:23-25) toward the teaching found in Romans 12:17-19. Cf also Proverb 25:21-23

1.verse: The Proverbs of Solomon, the son of David, king of Israel:

2.verse: That men may appreciate wisdom and discipline, may understand words of intelligence;

3.verse: May receive training in wise conduct, in what is right, just and honest;

4.verse: That resourcefulness may be imparted to the simple, to the young man knowledge and discretion.

5.verse: A wise man by hearing them will advance in learning, an intelligent man will gain sound guidance,

6.verse: That he may comprehend proverb and parable, the words of the wise and their riddles.

7.verse: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge; wisdom and instruction fools despise.

8.verse: Hear, my son, your father's instruction, and reject not your mother's teaching;

9.verse: A graceful diadem will they be for your head; a torque for your neck.

10.verse: My son, should sinners entice you,

11.verse: and say, "Come along with us! Let us lie in wait for the honest man, let us, unprovoked, set a trap for the innocent;

12.verse: Let us swallow them up, as the nether world does, alive, in the prime of life, like those who go down to the pit!

13.verse: All kinds of precious wealth shall we gain, we shall fill our houses with booty;

14.verse: Cast in your lot with us, we shall all have one purse!" -

15.verse: My son, walk not in the way with them, hold back your foot from their path!

16.verse: (For their feet run to evil, they hasten to shed blood.)

17.verse: It is in vain that a net is spread before the eyes of any bird -

18.verse: These men lie in wait for their own blood, they set a trap for their own lives.

19.verse: This is the fate of everyone greedy of loot: unlawful gain takes away the life of him who acquires it.

20.verse: Wisdom cries aloud in the street, in the open squares she raises her voice;

21.verse: Down the crowded ways she calls out, at the city gates she utters her words:

22.verse: "How long, you simple ones, will you love inanity,

23.verse: how long will you turn away at my reproof? Lo! I will pour out to you my spirit, I will acquaint you with my words.

24.verse: "Because I called and you refused, I extended my hand and no one took notice;

25.verse: Because you disdained all my counsel, and my reproof you ignored -

26.verse: I, in my turn, will laugh at your doom; I will mock when terror overtakes you;

27.verse: When terror comes upon you like a storm, and your doom approaches like a whirlwind; when distress and anguish befall you.

28.verse: "Then they call me, but I answer not; they seek me, but find me not;

29.verse: Because they hated knowledge, and chose not the fear of the LORD;

30.verse: They ignored my counsel, they spurned all my reproof; And in their arrogance they preferred arrogance, and like fools they hated knowledge:

31.verse: "Now they must eat the fruit of their own way, and with their own devices be glutted.

32.verse: For the self-will of the simple kills them, the smugness of fools destroys them.

33.verse: But he who obeys me dwells in security, in peace, without fear of harm."

annotations.1: [1-6] This prologue explains the purpose of the book: to educate the inexperienced in knowledge and right conduct, and to increase the learning of the wise man by proverbs, parables and riddles.
annotations.2: [2] Discipline: education or formation which dispels ignorance and corrects vice
annotations.3: [4] Simple: immature and inexperienced, hence easily influenced for good or evil
annotations.4: [7] Fear of the LORD: reverential fear and respect for God on account of his sovereignty, goodness and justice toward men. This is the foundation of religion
annotations.5: [8-19] A warning against association with the greedy and the violent who seek to destroy the honest man and to steal his possessions ( Proverb 1:11-14). The trap which the wicked set for the innocent ( Proverb 1:11), in the end ( Proverb 1:19) takes away the life of the wicked themselves
annotations.6: [17] Instructed by the wise man, the youth (of Proverb 1:4) will recognize the invitation of the wicked ( Proverb 1:11-14) as a net spread before him, and he will thus, like the bird, be protected against falling into it
annotations.7: [20-33] Wisdom is here personified; with divine authority she sets forth and proclaims the moral order, instructing and threatening ( Proverb 1:24-33) the multitudes in the streets and places of assembly
annotations.8: [28] Overtaken by doom, the foolish seek wisdom, but in vain because they do so too late. Cf John 7:34; 8:21
annotations.9: [31] Sinners are punished by the bad fruits which their sins produce. Cf Wisdom 11:16

1.verse: Better a dry crust with peace than a house full of feasting with strife.

2.verse: An intelligent servant will rule over a worthless son, and will share the inheritance with the brothers.

3.verse: The crucible for silver, and the furnace for gold, but the tester of hearts is the LORD.

4.verse: The evil man gives heed to wicked lips, and listens to falsehood from a mischievous tongue.

5.verse: He who mocks the poor blasphemes his Maker; he who is glad at calamity will not go unpunished.

6.verse: Grandchildren are the crown of old men, and the glory of children is their parentage.

7.verse: Fine words are out of place in a fool; how much more, lying words in a noble!

8.verse: A man who has a bribe to offer rates it a magic stone; at every turn it brings him success.

9.verse: He who covers up a misdeed fosters friendship, but he who gossips about it separates friends.

10.verse: A single reprimand does more for a man of intelligence than a hundred lashes for a fool.

11.verse: On rebellion alone is the wicked man bent, but a merciless messenger will be sent against him.

12.verse: Face a bear robbed of her cubs, but never a fool in his folly!

13.verse: If a man returns evil for good, from his house evil will not depart.

14.verse: The start of strife is like the opening of a dam; therefore, check a quarrel before it begins!

15.verse: He who condones the wicked, he who condemns the just, are both an abomination to the LORD.

16.verse: Of what use in the fool's hand are the means to buy wisdom, since he has no mind for it?

17.verse: He who is a friend is always a friend, and a brother is born for the time of stress.

18.verse: Senseless is the man who gives his hand in pledge, who becomes surety for his neighbor.

19.verse: He who loves strife loves guilt; he who builds his gate high courts disaster.

20.verse: He who is perverse in heart finds no good, and a double-tongued man falls into trouble.

21.verse: To be a fool's parent is grief for a man; the father of a numskull has no joy.

22.verse: A joyful heart is the health of the body, but a depressed spirit dries up the bones.

23.verse: The wicked man accepts a concealed bribe to pervert the course of justice.

24.verse: The man of intelligence fixes his gaze on wisdom, but the eyes of a fool are on the ends of the earth.

25.verse: A foolish son is vexation to his father, and bitter sorrow to her who bore him.

26.verse: It is wrong to fine an innocent man, but beyond reason to scourge princes.

27.verse: He who spares his words is truly wise, and he who is chary of speech is a man of intelligence.

28.verse: Even a fool, if he keeps silent, is considered wise; if he closes his lips, intelligent.

annotations.1: [2] Intelligence and ability are esteemed more highly than nobility of blood.
annotations.2: [4] To justify his own evil ways, a wicked man judges evil of others. Cf Matthew 7:1-5
annotations.3: [19] Builds . . . high: a symbol of arrogance

1.verse: My son, keep my words, and treasure my commands.

2.verse: Keep my commands and live, my teaching as the apple of your eye;

3.verse: Bind them on your fingers, write them on the tablet of your heart.

4.verse: Say to Wisdom, "You are my sister!" call Understanding, "Friend!"

5.verse: That they may keep you from another's wife, from the adulteress with her smooth words.

6.verse: For at the window of my house, through my lattice I looked out -

7.verse: And I saw among the simple ones, I observed among the young men, a youth with no sense,

8.verse: Going along the street near the corner, then walking in the direction of her house -

9.verse: In the twilight, at dusk of day, at the time of the dark of night.

10.verse: And lo! the woman comes to meet him, robed like a harlot, with secret designs -

11.verse: She is fickle and unruly, in her home her feet cannot rest;

12.verse: Now she is in the streets, now in the open squares, and at every corner she lurks in ambush -

13.verse: When she seizes him, she kisses him, and with an impudent look says to him:

14.verse: "I owed peace offerings, and today I have fulfilled my vows;

15.verse: So I came out to meet you, to look for you, and I have found you!

16.verse: With coverlets I have spread my couch, with brocaded cloths of Egyptian linen;

17.verse: I have sprinkled my bed with myrrh, with aloes, and with cinnamon.

18.verse: "Come, let us drink our fill of love, until morning, let us feast on love!

19.verse: For my husband is not at home, he has gone on a long journey;

20.verse: A bag of money he took with him, not till the full moon will he return home."

21.verse: She wins him over by her repeated urging, with her smooth lips she leads him astray;

22.verse: He follows her stupidly, like an ox that is led to slaughter; Like a stag that minces toward the net,

23.verse: till an arrow pierces its liver; Like a bird that rushes into a snare, unaware that its life is at stake.

24.verse: So now, O children, listen to me, be attentive to the words of my mouth!

25.verse: Let not your heart turn to her ways, go not astray in her paths;

26.verse: For many are those she has struck down dead, numerous, those she has slain.

27.verse: Her house is made up of ways to the nether world, leading down into the chambers of death

annotations.1: [14] "Peace offerings . . . vows": a portion of the sacrifice reverted to the donor and had to be eaten on the same day at a family festival ( Lev 7:11-15). In this figure, the adulteress offers to share with the foolish young man the deadly feast of her sensuality.

1.verse: The man who remains stiff-necked and hates rebuke will be crushed suddenly beyond cure.

2.verse: When the just prevail, the people rejoice; but when the wicked rule, the people groan.

3.verse: He who loves wisdom makes his father glad, but he who consorts with harlots squanders his wealth.

4.verse: By justice a king gives stability to the land; but he who imposes heavy taxes ruins it.

5.verse: The man who flatters his neighbor is spreading a net under his feet.

6.verse: The wicked man steps into a snare, but the just man runs on joyfully.

7.verse: The just man has a care for the rights of the poor; the wicked man has no such concern.

8.verse: Arrogant men set the city ablaze, but wise men calm the fury.

9.verse: If a wise man disputes with a fool, he may rage or laugh but can have no peace.

10.verse: Bloodthirsty men hate the honest man, but the upright show concern for his life.

11.verse: The fool gives vent to all his anger; but by biding his time, the wise man calms it.

12.verse: If a ruler listens to lying words, his servants all become wicked.

13.verse: The poor and the oppressor have a common bond: the LORD gives light to the eyes of both.

14.verse: If a king is zealous for the rights of the poor, his throne stands firm forever.

15.verse: The rod of correction gives wisdom, but a boy left to his whims disgraces his mother.

16.verse: When the wicked prevail, crime increases; but their downfall the just will behold.

17.verse: Correct your son, and he will bring you comfort, and give delight to your soul.

18.verse: Without prophecy the people become demoralized; but happy is he who keeps the law.

19.verse: By words no servant can be trained; for he understands what is said, but obeys not.

20.verse: Do you see a man hasty in his words? More can be hoped for from a fool!

21.verse: If a man pampers his servant from childhood, he will turn out to be stubborn.

22.verse: An ill-tempered man stirs up disputes, and a hotheaded man is the cause of many sins.

23.verse: Man's pride causes his humiliation, but he who is humble of spirit obtains honor.

24.verse: The accomplice of a thief is his own enemy: he hears himself put under a curse, yet discloses nothing.

25.verse: The fear of man brings a snare, but he who trusts in the LORD is safe.

26.verse: Many curry favor with the ruler, but the rights of each are from the LORD.

27.verse: The evildoer is an abomination to the just, and he who walks uprightly is an abomination to the wicked.

annotations.1: [13] God gives life to all classes of people; cf Proverb 22:2.
annotations.2: [24] Is his own enemy: because he not only incurs guilt as an accomplice but, by his silence, brings down on himself the curse invoked on the unknown guilty partner

1.verse: These also are proverbs of Solomon. The men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, transmitted them.

2.verse: God has glory in what he conceals, kings have glory in what they fathom.

3.verse: As the heavens in height, and the earth in depth, the heart of kings is unfathomable.

4.verse: Remove the dross from silver, and it comes forth perfectly purified;

5.verse: Remove the wicked from the presence of the king, and his throne is made firm through righteousness.

6.verse: Claim no honor in the king's presence, nor occupy the place of great men;

7.verse: For it is better that you be told, "Come up closer!" than that you be humbled before the prince.

8.verse: What your eyes have seen bring not forth hastily against an opponent; For what will you do later on when your neighbor puts you to shame?

9.verse: Discuss your case with your neighbor, but another man's secret do not disclose;

10.verse: Lest, hearing it, he reproach you, and your ill repute cease not.

11.verse: Like golden apples in silver settings are words spoken at the proper time.

12.verse: Like a golden earring, or a necklace of fine gold, is a wise reprover to an obedient ear.

13.verse: Like the coolness of snow in the heat of the harvest is a faithful messenger for the one who sends him. (He refreshes the soul of his master.)

14.verse: Like clouds and wind when no rain follows is the man who boastfully promises what he never gives.

15.verse: By patience is a ruler persuaded, and a soft tongue will break a bone.

16.verse: If you find honey, eat only what you need, lest you become glutted with it and vomit it up.

17.verse: Let your foot be seldom in your neighbor's house, lest he have more than enough of you, and hate you.

18.verse: Like a club, or a sword, or a sharp arrow, is the man who bears false witness against his neighbor.

19.verse: Like an infected tooth or an unsteady foot is (dependence on) a faithless man in time of trouble.

20.verse: Like a moth in clothing, or a maggot in wood, sorrow gnaws at the human heart.

21.verse: If your enemy be hungry, give him food to eat, if he be thirsty, give him to drink;

22.verse: For live coals you will heap on his head, and the LORD will vindicate you.

23.verse: The north wind brings rain, and a backbiting tongue an angry countenance.

24.verse: It is better to dwell in a corner of the housetop than in a roomy house with a quarrelsome woman.

25.verse: Like cool water to one faint from thirst is good news from a far country.

26.verse: Like a troubled fountain or a polluted spring is a just man who gives way before the wicked.

27.verse: To eat too much honey is not good; nor to seek honor after honor.

28.verse: Like an open city with no defenses is the man with no check on his feelings.

annotations.1: The men of Hezekiah: literary men at the royal court of Hezekiah who are represented as transcribing the proverbs from other collections. Hezekiah was a reformer of national religious life ( 2 Chron 29:25-30).
annotations.2: [6-7] Compare the lesson on humility which was taught by Christ ( Luke 14:7-11)
annotations.3: [21-22] Charity is invaluable in resolving enmities and restoring peace. Live coals: i.e., either remorse and embarrassment for the harm done, or increased punishment for refusing reconciliation. Cf Matthew 5:44; Romans 12:20
annotations.4: [27] Nor . . . honor after honor: the text is uncertain

1.verse: The words of Agur, son of Jakeh the Massaite: The pronouncement of mortal man: "I am not God; I am not God, that I should prevail.

2.verse: Why, I am the most stupid of men, and have not even human intelligence;

3.verse: Neither have I learned wisdom, nor have I the knowledge of the Holy One.

4.verse: Who has gone up to heaven and come down again - who has cupped the wind in his hands? Who has bound up the waters in a cloak - who has marked out all the ends of the earth? What is his name, what is his son's name, if you know it?"

5.verse: Every word of God is tested; he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.

6.verse: Add nothing to his words, lest he reprove you, and you be exposed as a deceiver.

7.verse: Two things I ask of you, deny them not to me before I die:

8.verse: Put falsehood and lying far from me, give me neither poverty nor riches; (provide me only with the food I need;)

9.verse: Lest, being full, I deny you, saying, "Who is the LORD?" Or, being in want, I steal, and profane the name of my God.

10.verse: Slander not a servant to his master, lest he curse you, and you have to pay the penalty.

11.verse: There is a group of people that curses its father, and blesses not its mother.

12.verse: There is a group that is pure in its own eyes, yet is not purged of its filth.

13.verse: There is a group - how haughty their eyes! how overbearing their glance!

14.verse: There is a group whose incisors are swords, whose teeth are knives, Devouring the needy from the earth, and the poor from among men.

15.verse: The two daughters of the leech are, "Give, Give." Three things are never satisfied, four never say, "Enough!"

16.verse: The nether world, and the barren womb; the earth, that is never saturated with water, and fire, that never says, "Enough!"

17.verse: The eye that mocks a father, or scorns an aged mother, Will be plucked out by the ravens in the valley; the young eagles will devour it.

18.verse: Three things are too wonderful for me, yes, four I cannot understand:

19.verse: The way of an eagle in the air, the way of a serpent upon a rock, The way of a ship on the high seas, and the way of a man with a maiden.

20.verse: Such is the way of an adulterous woman: she eats, wipes her mouth, and says, "I have done no wrong."

21.verse: Under three things the earth trembles, yes, under four it cannot bear up:

22.verse: Under a slave when he becomes king, and a fool when he is glutted with food;

23.verse: Under an odious woman when she is wed, and a maidservant when she displaces her mistress.

24.verse: Four things are among the smallest on the earth, and yet are exceedingly wise:

25.verse: Ants - a species not strong, yet they store up their food in the summer;

26.verse: Rock-badgers - a species not mighty, yet they make their home in the crags;

27.verse: Locusts - they have no king, yet they migrate all in array;

28.verse: Lizards - you can catch them with your hands, yet they find their way into king's palaces.

29.verse: Three things are stately in their stride, yes, four are stately in their carriage:

30.verse: The lion, mightiest of beasts, who retreats before nothing;

31.verse: The strutting cock, and the he-goat, and the king at the head of his people.

32.verse: If you have foolishly been proud or presumptuous - put your hand on your mouth;

33.verse: For the stirring of milk brings forth curds, and the stirring of anger brings forth blood.

annotations.1: [1-3] Agur wishes to stress man's insignificance when he is compared to God; cf Job 38-39
annotations.2: [1] Agur: an unknown person. Massaite: from Massa in northern Arabia, elsewhere referred to as an encampment of the Ishmaelites ( Genesis 25:14). But the word may not be intended as a place name; it might signify "an oracle," "a prophecy."
annotations.3: [11-14] Perverted people are here classified as unfilial ( Proverb 30:11), self-righteous ( Proverb 30:12), proud ( Proverb 30:13) and rapacious ( Proverb 30:14)
annotations.4: [15-17] The two daughters . . . "Give, Give": the text is obscure but the sense seems to be that the leech is insatiable in its desire for blood, just as desire for blood, just as are the nether world for victims, the barren womb for offspring, the parched earth for water, and fire for fuel ( Proverb 30:16)
annotations.5: [18-19] The soaring flight of the eagle, the mysterious movement upon a rock of the serpent which has no feet, the path of the ship through the trackless deep, and the marvelous procreation of human life, excite great wonderment
annotations.6: [20] This verse portrays the indifference of an adulterous woman who thinks there is no trace of her wicked act
annotations.8: [32-33] The anger aroused by overweening pride threatens an awesome punishment

1.verse: My son, forget not my teaching, keep in mind my commands;

2.verse: For many days, and years of life, and peace, will they bring you.

3.verse: Let not kindness and fidelity leave you; bind them around your neck;

4.verse: Then will you win favor and good esteem before God and man.

5.verse: Trust in the LORD with all your heart, on your own intelligence rely not;

6.verse: In all your ways be mindful of him, and he will make straight your paths.

7.verse: Be not wise in your own eyes, fear the LORD and turn away from evil;

8.verse: This will mean health for your flesh and vigor for your bones.

9.verse: Honor the LORD with your wealth, with first fruits of all your produce;

10.verse: Then will your barns be filled with grain, with new wine your vats will overflow.

11.verse: The discipline of the LORD, my son, disdain not; spurn not his reproof;

12.verse: For whom the LORD loves he reproves, and he chastises the son he favors.

13.verse: Happy the man who finds wisdom, the man who gains understanding!

14.verse: For her profit is better than profit in silver, and better than gold is her revenue;

15.verse: She is more precious than corals, and none of your choice possessions can compare with her.

16.verse: Long life is in her right hand, in her left are riches and honor;

17.verse: Her ways are pleasant ways, and all her paths are peace;

18.verse: She is a tree of life to those who grasp her, and he is happy who holds her fast.

19.verse: The LORD by wisdom founded the earth, established the heavens by understanding;

20.verse: By his knowledge the depths break open, and the clouds drop down dew.

21.verse: My son, let not these slip out of your sight: keep advice and counsel in view;

22.verse: So will they be life to your soul, and an adornment for your neck.

23.verse: Then you may securely go your way; your foot will never stumble;

24.verse: When you lie down, you need not be afraid, when you rest, your sleep will be sweet.

35.verse: Honor is the possession of wise men, but fools inherit shame.

25.verse: Be not afraid of sudden terror, of the ruin of the wicked when it comes;

26.verse: For the LORD will be your confidence, and will keep your foot from the snare.

27.verse: Refuse no one the good on which he has a claim when it is in your power to do it for him.

28.verse: Say not to your neighbor, "Go, and come again, tomorrow I will give," when you can give at once.

29.verse: Plot no evil against your neighbor, against him who lives at peace with you.

30.verse: Quarrel not with a man without cause, with one who has done you no harm.

31.verse: Envy not the lawless man and choose none of his ways:

32.verse: To the LORD the perverse man is an abomination, but with the upright is his friendship.

33.verse: The curse of the LORD is on the house of the wicked, but the dwelling of the just he blesses;

34.verse: When he is dealing with the arrogant, he is stern, but to the humble he shows kindness.

annotations.1: [1-12] Many are the rewards for fidelity and trust in God, and for diffidence of self ( Proverb 3:1-8). Cf Deut 30:20; Isaiah 38:19. The offering of material things for divine worship is blessed by an increase of such goods ( Proverb 3:9-10). Even correction and chastisement are a mark of God's love and favor ( Proverb 3:11-12).
annotations.2: [13-24] Wisdom, or understanding, is more valuable than silver and gold. Its fruit is long life, riches, honor and happiness ( Proverb 3:13-18). Even the creation of the universe and its adornment (Genesis 1) were not done without wisdom ( Proverb 3:19-20). It is the life of the soul and gives security in work and in repose ( Proverb 3:21-24)
annotations.3: [15] Corals: some precious stone may be intended
annotations.4: [18] A tree of life: cf Proverb 11:30; 13:12; Genesis 2:9
annotations.5: [20] For the Hebrews, the depths enclosed the great subterranean ocean; the rain and dew descended from the celestial ocean above the firmament; cf Genesis 1:6-10; Job 26:8, 12; Psalm 18:15; 24:2
annotations.6: [25-34] Serving God with confidence in him ( Proverb 3:25-26) requires serving one's neighbor through kindness ( Proverb 3:27- 28), peace with the good ( Proverb 3:29-31), no envy of the wicked ( Proverb 3:31), because the Lord's friendship and kindness are with the just; his curse is with the wicked
annotations.7: [25] The ruin of the wicked: i.e., the ruin that comes upon the wicked

1.verse: The Proverbs of Solomon: A wise son makes his father glad, but a foolish son is a grief to his mother.

2.verse: Ill-gotten treasures profit nothing, but virtue saves from death.

3.verse: The LORD permits not the just to hunger, but the craving of the wicked he thwarts.

4.verse: The slack hand impoverishes, but the hand of the diligent enriches.

5.verse: A son who fills the granaries in summer is a credit; a son who slumbers during harvest, a disgrace.

6.verse: Blessings are for the head of the just, but a rod for the back of the fool.

7.verse: The memory of the just will be blessed, but the name of the wicked will rot.

8.verse: A wise man heeds commands, but a prating fool will be overthrown.

9.verse: He who walks honestly walks securely, but he whose ways are crooked will fare badly.

10.verse: He who winks at a fault causes trouble, but he who frankly reproves promotes peace.

11.verse: A fountain of life is the mouth of the just, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

12.verse: Hatred stirs up disputes, but love covers all offenses.

13.verse: On the lips of the intelligent is found wisdom, (but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence).

14.verse: Wise men store up knowledge, but the mouth of a fool is imminent ruin.

15.verse: The rich man's wealth is his strong city; the ruination of the lowly is their poverty.

16.verse: The just man's recompense leads to life, the gains of the wicked, to sin.

17.verse: A path to life is his who heeds admonition, but he who disregards reproof goes astray.

18.verse: It is the lips of the liar that conceal hostility; but he who spreads accusations is a fool.

19.verse: Where words are many, sin is not wanting; but he who restrains his lips does well.

20.verse: Like choice silver is the just man's tongue; the heart of the wicked is of little worth.

21.verse: The just man's lips nourish many, but fools die for want of sense.

22.verse: It is the LORD'S blessing that brings wealth, and no effort can substitute for it.

23.verse: Crime is the entertainment of the fool; so is wisdom for the man of sense.

24.verse: What the wicked man fears will befall him, but the desire of the just will be granted.

25.verse: When the tempest passes, the wicked man is no more; but the just man is established forever.

26.verse: As vinegar to the teeth, and smoke to the eyes, is the sluggard to those who use him as a messenger.

27.verse: The fear of the LORD prolongs life, but the years of the wicked are brief.

28.verse: The hope of the just brings them joy, but the expectation of the wicked comes to nought.

29.verse: The LORD is a stronghold to him who walks honestly, but to evildoers, their downfall.

30.verse: The just man will never be disturbed, but the wicked will not abide in the land.

31.verse: The mouth of the just yields wisdom, but the perverse tongue will be cut off.

32.verse: The lips of the just know how to please, but the mouth of the wicked, how to pervert.

annotations.1: [ 10:1- 22:16] The varied contents of this first collection of Solomon's proverbs apply mostly to individual life. Each of its three hundred and seventy-five proverbs is meant to be distinct from the others, developing one idea through contrasting parallelism in Prov 10-15, and a climactic treatment in Prov 16-22.
annotations.2: [12] Love covers all offenses: a favorite maxim of the Apostles; cf 1 Cor 13:7; James 5:20; 1 Peter 4:8; Proverb 17:9
annotations.3: [15] The inspired author reflects upon the reality of the power of money and the defeat of poverty, without approving these things
annotations.4: [22] The blessing of God rather than our own industry crowns our efforts with success; cf Psalm 127:1-2; Matthew 6:25-34

1.verse: Hear, O children, a father's instruction, be attentive, that you may gain understanding!

2.verse: Yes, excellent advice I give you; my teaching do not forsake.

3.verse: When I was my father's child, frail, yet the darling of my mother,

4.verse: He taught me, and said to me: "Let your heart hold fast my words: keep my commands, that you may live!

5.verse: "Get wisdom, get understanding! Do not forget or turn aside from the words I utter.

6.verse: Forsake her not, and she will preserve you; love her, and she will safeguard you;

7.verse: The beginning of wisdom is: get wisdom; at the cost of all you have, get understanding.

8.verse: Extol her, and she will exalt you; she will bring you honors if you embrace her;

9.verse: She will put on your head a graceful diadem; a glorious crown will she bestow on you."

10.verse: Hear, my son, and receive my words, and the years of your life shall be many.

11.verse: On the way of wisdom I direct you, I lead you on straightforward paths.

12.verse: When you walk, your step will not be impeded, and should you run, you will not stumble.

13.verse: Hold fast to instruction, never let her go; keep her, for she is your life.

14.verse: The path of the wicked enter not, walk not on the way of evil men;

15.verse: Shun it, cross it not, turn aside from it, and pass on.

16.verse: For they cannot rest unless they have done evil; to have made no one stumble steals away their sleep.

17.verse: For they eat the bread of wickedness and drink the wine of violence.

19.verse: The way of the wicked is like darkness; they know not on what they stumble.

18.verse: But the path of the just is like shining light, that grows in brilliance till perfect day.

20.verse: My son, to my words be attentive, to my sayings incline your ear;

21.verse: Let them not slip out of your sight, keep them within your heart;

22.verse: For they are life to those who find them, to man's whole being they are health.

23.verse: With closest custody, guard your heart, for in it are the sources of life.

24.verse: Put away from you dishonest talk, deceitful speech put far from you.

25.verse: Let your eyes look straight ahead and your glance be directly forward.

26.verse: Survey the path for your feet, and let all your ways be sure.

annotations.1: [1-9] The sage speaks as a father admonishing his children to secure wisdom at any cost.
annotations.2: [10-27] The way of wisdom leads directly to life ( Proverb 4:10-13); it is a light that grows brighter ( Proverb 4:19[18]). The wise man is bound to shun ( Proverb 4:14-17) the dark and violent path of the wicked ( Proverb 4:18[19]). Singleness of purpose and right conduct proceed from the heart of a wise man as from the source of life Prov ( 4:23-26); they save him from destruction on evil paths ( Proverb 4:27; 5:21-23)
annotations.3: [18] (18)Till perfect day: literally, "till the day is established"; this may refer to full daylight or to noonday

1.verse: In estrangement one seeks pretexts: with all persistence he picks a quarrel.

2.verse: The fool takes no delight in understanding, but rather in displaying what he thinks.

3.verse: With wickedness comes contempt, and with disgrace comes scorn.

4.verse: The words from a man's mouth are deep waters, but the source of wisdom is a flowing brook.

5.verse: It is not good to be partial to the guilty, and so to reject a rightful claim.

6.verse: The fool's lips lead him into strife, and his mouth provokes a beating.

7.verse: The fool's mouth is his ruin; his lips are a snare to his life.

8.verse: The words of a talebearer are like dainty morsels that sink into one's inmost being.

9.verse: The man who is slack in his work is own brother to the man who is destructive.

10.verse: The name of the LORD is a strong tower; the just man runs to it and is safe.

11.verse: The rich man's wealth is his strong city; he fancies it a high wall.

12.verse: Before his downfall a man's heart is haughty, but humility goes before honors.

13.verse: He who answers before he hears - his is the folly and the shame.

14.verse: A man's spirit sustains him in infirmity - but a broken spirit who can bear?

15.verse: The mind of the intelligent gains knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.

16.verse: A man's gift clears the way for him, and gains him access to great men.

17.verse: The man who pleads his case first seems to be in the right; then his opponent comes and puts him to the test.

18.verse: The lot puts an end to disputes, and is decisive in a controversy between the mighty.

19.verse: A brother is a better defense than a strong city, and a friend is like the bars of a castle.

20.verse: From the fruit of his mouth a man has his fill; with the yield of his lips he sates himself.

21.verse: Death and life are in the power of the tongue; those who make it a friend shall eat its fruit.

22.verse: He who finds a wife finds happiness; it is a favor he receives from the LORD.

23.verse: The poor man implores, but the rich man answers harshly.

24.verse: Some friends bring ruin on us, but a true friend is more loyal than a brother.

annotations.1: [10-11] Religion is a strong support and sure refuge in the struggle of life. The rich foolishly rely on their wealth for such support.
annotations.2: [12] Compare the Savior's words: "Whoever exalts himself shall be humbled, and whoever humbles himself shall be exalted" ( Matthew 23:12)
annotations.3: [13] To speak without first listening is characteristic of a fool; cf Proverb 10:14; Sirach 11:8
annotations.5: [20-21] Everyone must accept the consequences, of benefit or harm to himself, which his words produce

1.verse: Wine is arrogant, strong drink is riotous; none who goes astray for it is wise.

2.verse: The dread of the king is as when a lion roars; he who incurs his anger forfeits his life.

3.verse: It is honorable for a man to shun strife, while every fool starts a quarrel.

4.verse: In seedtime the sluggard plows not; when he looks for the harvest, it is not there.

5.verse: The intention in the human heart is like water far below the surface, but the man of intelligence draws it forth.

6.verse: Many are declared to be men of virtue: but who can find one worthy of trust?

7.verse: When a man walks in integrity and justice, happy are his children after him!

8.verse: A king seated on the throne of judgment dispels all evil with his glance.

9.verse: Who can say, "I have made my heart clean, I am cleansed of my sin"?

10.verse: Varying weights, varying measures, are both an abomination to the LORD.

11.verse: Even by his manners the child betrays whether his conduct is innocent and right.

12.verse: The ear that hears, and the eye that sees - the LORD has made them both.

13.verse: Love not sleep, lest you be reduced to poverty; eyes wide open mean abundant food.

14.verse: "Bad, bad!" says the buyer; but once he has gone his way, he boasts.

15.verse: Like gold or a wealth of corals, wise lips are a precious ornament.

16.verse: Take his garment who becomes surety for another, and for strangers yield it up!

17.verse: The bread of deceit is sweet to a man, but afterward his mouth will be filled with gravel.

18.verse: Plans made after advice succeed; so with wise guidance wage your war.

19.verse: A newsmonger reveals secrets; so have nothing to do with a babbler!

20.verse: If one curses his father or mother, his lamp will go out at the coming of darkness.

21.verse: Possessions gained hastily at the outset will in the end not be blessed.

22.verse: Say not, "I will repay evil!" Trust in the LORD and he will help you.

23.verse: Varying weights are an abomination to the LORD, and false scales are not good.

24.verse: Man's steps are from the LORD; how, then, can a man understand his way?

26.verse: A wise king winnows the wicked, and threshes them under the cartwheel.

27.verse: A lamp from the LORD is the breath of man; it searches through all his inmost being.

28.verse: Kindness and piety safeguard the king, and he upholds his throne by justice.

29.verse: The glory of young men is their strength, and the dignity of old men is gray hair.

30.verse: Evil is cleansed away by bloody lashes, and a scourging to the inmost being.

annotations.2: [14] What one wishes to buy is valued cheaply in order that it may be obtained at a low price; once purchased, it is deemed more valuable
