1.verse: Wisdom has built her house, she has set up her seven columns;

2.verse: She has dressed her meat, mixed her wine, yes, she has spread her table.

3.verse: She has sent out her maidens; she calls from the heights out over the city:

4.verse: "Let whoever is simple turn in here; to him who lacks understanding, I say,

5.verse: Come, eat of my food, and drink of the wine I have mixed!

6.verse: Forsake foolishness that you may live; advance in the way of understanding.

11.verse: For by me your days will be multiplied and the years of your life increased."

7.verse: He who corrects an arrogant man earns insult; and he who reproves a wicked man incurs opprobrium.

8.verse: Reprove not an arrogant man, lest he hate you; reprove a wise man, and he will love you.

9.verse: Instruct a wise man, and he becomes still wiser; teach a just man, and he advances in learning.

10.verse: The beginning of wisdom is the fear of the LORD, and knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.

12.verse: If you are wise, it is to your own advantage; and if you are arrogant, you alone shall bear it.

13.verse: The woman Folly is fickle, she is inane, and knows nothing.

14.verse: She sits at the door of her house upon a seat on the city heights,

15.verse: Calling to passers-by as they go on their straight way:

16.verse: "Let whoever is simple turn in here, or who lacks understanding; for to him I say,

17.verse: Stolen water is sweet, and bread gotten secretly is pleasing!"

18.verse: Little he knows that the shades are there, that in the depths of the nether world are her guests!

annotations.1: [1-6,13-18] Wisdom and folly are represented as matrons, each inviting people to her banquet. Wisdom offers the food and drink of divine doctrine and virtue which give life ( Proverb 9:1-6). Unstable and senseless folly furnishes the stolen bread and water of deceit and vice which bring death to her guests.
annotations.2: [3] She calls: i.e., indirectly, through her maidens; but the text could also mean that wisdom herself publicly proclaims her invitation
annotations.3: [17] The secrecy implies wrongdoing
annotations.4: [18] The banquet chamber of folly is a tomb from which no one who enters it is released

1.verse: Like snow in summer, or rain in harvest, honor for a fool is out of place.

2.verse: Like the sparrow in its flitting, like the swallow in its flight, a curse uncalled-for arrives nowhere.

3.verse: The whip for the horse, the bridle for the ass, and the rod for the back of fools.

4.verse: Answer not the fool according to his folly, lest you too become like him.

5.verse: Answer the fool according to his folly, lest he become wise in his own eyes.

6.verse: He cuts off his feet, he drinks down violence, who sends messages by a fool.

7.verse: A proverb in the mouth of a fool hangs limp, like crippled legs.

8.verse: Like one who entangles the stone in the sling is he who gives honor to a fool.

9.verse: Like a thorn stick brandished by the hand of a drunkard is a proverb in the mouth of fools.

10.verse: Like an archer wounding all who pass by is he who hires a drunken fool.

11.verse: As the dog returns to his vomit, so the fool repeats his folly.

12.verse: You see a man wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for him.

13.verse: The sluggard says, "There is a lion in the street, a lion in the middle of the square!"

14.verse: The door turns on its hinges, the sluggard, on his bed!

15.verse: The sluggard loses his hand in the dish; he is too weary to lift it to his mouth.

16.verse: The sluggard imagines himself wiser than seven men who answer with good sense.

17.verse: Like the man who seizes a passing dog by the ears is he who meddles in a quarrel not his own.

18.verse: Like a crazed archer scattering firebrands and deadly arrows

19.verse: Is the man who deceives his neighbor, and then says, "I was only joking."

20.verse: For lack of wood, the fire dies out; and when there is no talebearer, strife subsides.

21.verse: What a bellows is to live coals, what wood is to fire, such is a contentious man in enkindling strife.

22.verse: The words of a talebearer are like dainty morsels that sink into one's inmost being.

23.verse: Like a glazed finish on earthenware are smooth lips with a wicked heart.

24.verse: With his lips an enemy pretends, but in his inmost being he maintains deceit;

25.verse: When he speaks graciously, trust him not, for seven abominations are in his heart.

26.verse: A man may conceal hatred under dissimulation, but his malice will be revealed in the assembly.

27.verse: He who digs a pit falls into it; and a stone comes back upon him who rolls it.

28.verse: The lying tongue is its owner's enemy, and the flattering mouth works ruin.

annotations.1: [1-28] Concrete images describe the vices of fools ( Proverb 26:1-12), of sluggards ( Proverb 26:13-16), of meddlers ( Proverb 26:17-19), of talebearers ( Proverb 26:20-22), and of flatterers ( Proverb 26:23-28).
annotations.2: [4-5] There is no contradiction between these two proverbs. In any answer the wise man gives he must protect his own interest against the fool
annotations.3: [7-9] The fool abuses whatever knowledge he possesses

1.verse: When you sit down to dine with a ruler, keep in mind who is before you;

2.verse: And put a knife to your throat if you have a ravenous appetite.

3.verse: Do not desire his delicacies; they are deceitful food.

4.verse: Toil not to gain wealth, cease to be concerned about it;

5.verse: While your glance flits to it, it is gone! for assuredly it grows wings, like the eagle that flies toward heaven.

6.verse: Do not take food with a grudging man, and do not desire his dainties;

7.verse: For in his greed he is like a storm. "Eat and drink," he says to you, though his heart is not with you;

8.verse: The little you have eaten you will vomit up, and you will have wasted your agreeable words.

9.verse: Speak not for the fool's hearing; he will despise the wisdom of your words.

10.verse: Remove not the ancient landmark, nor invade the fields of orphans;

11.verse: For their redeemer is strong; he will defend their cause against you.

12.verse: Apply your heart to instruction, and your ears to words of knowledge.

13.verse: Withhold not chastisement from a boy; if you beat him with the rod, he will not die.

14.verse: Beat him with the rod, and you will save him from the nether world.

15.verse: My son, if your heart be wise, my own heart also will rejoice;

16.verse: And my inmost being will exult, when your lips speak what is right.

17.verse: Let not your heart emulate sinners, but be zealous for the fear of the LORD always;

18.verse: For you will surely have a future, and your hope will not be cut off.

19.verse: Hear, my son, and be wise, and guide your heart in the right way.

20.verse: Consort not with winebibbers, nor with those who eat meat to excess;

21.verse: For the drunkard and the glutton come to poverty, and torpor clothes a man in rags.

22.verse: Listen to your father who begot you, and despise not your mother when she is old.

23.verse: Get the truth, and sell it not - wisdom, instruction and understanding.

24.verse: The father of a just man will exult with glee; he who begets a wise son will have joy in him.

25.verse: Let your father and mother have joy; let her who bore you exult.

26.verse: My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes keep to my ways.

27.verse: For the harlot is a deep ditch, and the adulteress a narrow pit;

28.verse: Yes, she lies in wait like a robber, and increases the faithless among men.

29.verse: Who scream? Who shriek? Who have strife? Who have anxiety? Who have wounds for nothing? Who have black eyes?

30.verse: Those who linger long over wine, those who engage in trials of blended wine.

31.verse: Look not on the wine when it is red, when it sparkles in the glass. It goes down smoothly;

32.verse: but in the end it bites like a serpent, or like a poisonous adder.

33.verse: Your eyes behold strange sights, and your heart utters disordered thoughts;

34.verse: You are like one now lying in the depths of the sea, now sprawled at the top of the mast.

35.verse: "They struck me, but it pained me not; They beat me, but I felt it not; When shall I awake to seek wine once again?"

annotations.1: [2] Put a knife to your throat: a metaphor for self-restraint.
annotations.2: [29-35] A vivid description of the evil effects, physical and psychological, of drunkenness
annotations.3: [35] Wine makes the drunkard insensible to bodily and moral harm. His one desire is to indulge again

1.verse: My son, to my wisdom be attentive, to my knowledge incline your ear,

2.verse: That discretion may watch over you, and understanding may guard you.

3.verse: The lips of an adulteress drip with honey, and her mouth is smoother than oil;

4.verse: But in the end she is as bitter as wormwood, as sharp as a two-edged sword.

5.verse: Her feet go down to death, to the nether world her steps attain;

7.verse: So now, O children, listen to me, go not astray from the words of my mouth.

8.verse: Keep your way far from her, approach not the door of her house,

9.verse: Lest you give your honor to others, and your years to a merciless one;

10.verse: Lest strangers have their fill of your wealth, your hard-won earnings go to an alien's house;

11.verse: And you groan in the end, when your flesh and your body are consumed;

12.verse: And you say, "Oh, why did I hate instruction, and my heart spurn reproof!

13.verse: Why did I not listen to the voice of my teachers, nor to my instructors incline my ear!

14.verse: I have all but come to utter ruin, condemned by the public assembly!"

15.verse: Drink water from your own cistern, running water from your own well.

16.verse: How may your water sources be dispersed abroad, streams of water in the streets?

17.verse: Let your fountain be yours alone, not one shared with strangers;

18.verse: And have joy of the wife of your youth,

19.verse: your lovely hind, your graceful doe. Her love will invigorate you always, through her love you will flourish continually,

20.verse: Why then, my son, should you go astray for another's wife and accept the embraces of an adulteress?

21.verse: For each man's ways are plain to the LORD'S sight; all their paths he surveys;

22.verse: By his own iniquities the wicked man will be caught, in the meshes of his own sin he will be held fast;

23.verse: He will die from lack of discipline, through the greatness of his folly he will be lost.

annotations.1: [1-20] Understanding and discretion guard a man against the wiles of an adulteress, which lead astray and beget bitterness, bloodshed and death ( Proverb 5:1-6). They destroy honor, waste the years of life, despoil hard-earned wealth, consume the flesh, and bring remorse in the end ( Proverb 5:7-14). Conjugal fidelity and love for one wife only bring happiness and security ( Proverb 5:15-20). Cf Proverb 6:20- 7:27.
annotations.2: [9] Honor: the words "life" and "wealth" have also been read in this place. A merciless one: the offended husband; cf Proverb 6:34-35
annotations.3: [19] Lovely hind . . . graceful doe: oriental symbols of feminine beauty and charm; cf Song 2:7, 9, 17
annotations.4: [21-23] These verses are best read after Proverb 5:27

1.verse: Wisdom builds her house, but Folly tears hers down with her own hands.

2.verse: He who walks uprightly fears the LORD, but he who is devious in his ways spurns him.

3.verse: In the mouth of the fool is a rod for his back, but the lips of the wise preserve them.

4.verse: Where there are no oxen, the crib remains empty; but large crops come through the strength of the bull.

5.verse: A truthful witness does not lie, but a false witness utters lies.

6.verse: The senseless man seeks in vain for wisdom, but knowledge is easy to the man of intelligence.

7.verse: To avoid the foolish man, take steps! But knowing lips one meets with by surprise.

8.verse: The shrewd man's wisdom gives him knowledge of his way, but the folly of fools is their deception.

9.verse: Guilt lodges in the tents of the arrogant, but favor in the house of the just.

10.verse: The heart knows its own bitterness, and in its joy no one else shares.

11.verse: The house of the wicked will be destroyed, but the tent of the upright will flourish.

12.verse: Sometimes a way seems right to a man, but the end of it leads to death!

13.verse: Even in laughter the heart may be sad, and the end of joy may be sorrow.

14.verse: The scoundrel suffers the consequences of his ways, and the good man reaps the fruit of his paths.

15.verse: The simpleton believes everything, but the shrewd man measures his steps.

16.verse: The wise man is cautious and shuns evil; the fool is reckless and sure of himself.

17.verse: The quick-tempered man makes a fool of himself, but the prudent man is at peace.

18.verse: The adornment of simpletons is folly, but shrewd men gain the crown of knowledge.

19.verse: Evil men must bow down before the good, and the wicked, at the gates of the just.

20.verse: Even by his neighbor the poor man is hated, but the friends of the rich are many.

21.verse: He sins who despises the hungry; but happy is he who is kind to the poor!

22.verse: Do not those who plot evil go astray? But those intent on good gain kindness and constancy.

23.verse: In all labor there is profit, but mere talk tends only to penury.

24.verse: The crown of the wise is resourcefulness; the diadem of fools is folly.

25.verse: The truthful witness saves lives, but he who utters lies is a betrayer.

26.verse: In the fear of the LORD is a strong defense; even for one's children he will be a refuge.

27.verse: The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, that a man may avoid the snares of death.

28.verse: In many subjects lies the glory of the king; but if his people are few, it is the prince's ruin.

29.verse: The patient man shows much good sense, but the quick-tempered man displays folly at its height.

30.verse: A tranquil mind gives life to the body, but jealousy rots the bones.

31.verse: He who oppresses the poor blasphemes his Maker, but he who is kind to the needy glorifies him.

32.verse: The wicked man is overthrown by his wickedness, but the just man finds a refuge in his honesty.

33.verse: In the heart of the intelligent wisdom abides, but in the bosom of fools it is unknown.

34.verse: Virtue exalts a nation, but sin is a people's disgrace.

35.verse: The king favors the intelligent servant, but the worthless one incurs his wrath.

1.verse: False scales are an abomination to the LORD, but a full weight is his delight.

2.verse: When pride comes, disgrace comes; but with the humble is wisdom.

3.verse: The honesty of the upright guides them; the faithless are ruined by their duplicity.

4.verse: Wealth is useless on the day of wrath, but virtue saves from death.

5.verse: The honest man's virtue makes his way straight, but by his wickedness the wicked man falls.

6.verse: The virtue of the upright saves them, but the faithless are caught in their own intrigue.

7.verse: When a wicked man dies his hope perishes, and what is expected from strength comes to nought.

8.verse: The just man escapes trouble, and the wicked man falls into it in his stead.

9.verse: With his mouth the impious man would ruin his neighbor, but through their knowledge the just make their escape.

10.verse: When the just prosper, the city rejoices; and when the wicked perish, there is jubilation.

11.verse: Through the blessing of the righteous the city is exalted, but through the mouth of the wicked it is overthrown.

12.verse: He who reviles his neighbor has no sense, but the intelligent man keeps silent.

13.verse: A newsmonger reveals secrets, but a trustworthy man keeps a confidence.

14.verse: For lack of guidance a people falls; security lies in many counselors.

15.verse: He is in a bad way who becomes surety for another, but he who hates giving pledges is safe.

16.verse: A gracious woman wins esteem, but she who hates virtue is covered with shame. (The slothful become impoverished, but the diligent gain wealth.)

17.verse: A kindly man benefits himself, but a merciless man harms himself.

18.verse: The wicked man makes empty profits, but he who sows virture has a sure reward.

19.verse: Virtue directs toward life, but he who pursues evil does so to his death.

20.verse: The depraved in heart are an abomination to the LORD, but those who walk blamelessly are his delight.

21.verse: Truly the evil man shall not go unpunished, but those who are just shall escape.

22.verse: Like a golden ring in a swine's snout is a beautiful woman with a rebellious disposition.

23.verse: The desire of the just ends only in good; the expectation of the wicked is wrath.

24.verse: One man is lavish yet grows still richer; another is too sparing, yet is the poorer.

25.verse: He who confers benefits will be amply enriched, and he who refreshes others will himself be refreshed.

26.verse: Him who monopolizes grain, the people curse - but blessings upon the head of him who distributes it!

27.verse: He who seeks the good commands favor, but he who pursues evil will have evil befall him.

28.verse: He who trusts in his riches will fall, but like green leaves the just flourish.

29.verse: He who upsets his household has empty air for a heritage; and the fool will become slave to the wise man.

30.verse: The fruit of virtue is a tree of life, but violence takes lives away.

31.verse: If the just man is punished on earth, how much more the wicked and the sinner!

1.verse: Boast not of tomorrow, for you know not what any day may bring forth.

2.verse: Let another praise you - not your own mouth; Someone else - not your own lips.

3.verse: Stone is heavy, and sand a burden, but a fool's provocation is heavier than both.

4.verse: Anger is relentless, and wrath overwhelming - but before jealousy who can stand?

5.verse: Better is an open rebuke than a love that remains hidden.

6.verse: Wounds from a friend may be accepted as well meant, but the greetings of an enemy one prays against.

7.verse: One who is full, tramples on virgin honey; but to the man who is hungry, any bitter thing is sweet.

8.verse: Like a bird that is far from its nest is a man who is far from his home.

9.verse: Perfume and incense gladden the heart, but by grief the soul is torn asunder.

10.verse: Your own friend and your father's friend forsake not; but if ruin befalls you, enter not a kinsman's house. Better is a neighbor near at hand than a brother far away.

11.verse: If you are wise, my son, you will gladden my heart, and I will be able to rebut him who tuants me.

Proverbs
Introduction
The first word of this book, MISHLE, has provided the title by which it is generally designated in Jewish and Christian circles. The name "Proverbs," while not an exact equivalent of MISHLE, describes the main contents satisfactorily, even though it is hardly an adequate designation for such parts as Proverb 1:1- 9:18 or Proverb 31:10-31. Among some early Christian writers the book was also known by the name of "Wisdom," and in the Roman Missal it was referred to as a "Book of Wisdom.&quot
The Book of Proverbs is an anthology of didactic poetry forming part of the sapiential literature of the Old Testament. Its primary purpose, indicated in the first sentence ( Proverb 1:2, 3), is to teach wisdom. It is thus directed particularly to the young and inexperienced ( Proverb 1:4); but also to those who desire advanced training in wisdom ( Proverb 1:5, 6). The wisdom which the book teaches, covers a wide field of human and divine activity, ranging from matters purely secular to most lofty moral and religious truths, such as God's omniscience ( Proverb 5:21; 15:3-11), power ( Proverb 19:21; 21:30), providence ( Proverb 20:1-24), goodness ( Proverb 15:29), and the joy and strength resulting from abandonment to him ( Proverb 3:5; 16:20; 18:10). The teaching of the entire book is placed on a firm religious foundation by the principle that "the fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge" ( Proverb 1:7; cf Proverb 9:10)
To Solomon are explicitly ascribed parts II and V of the book; he is the patron of Hebrew wisdom. Of Agur (part VI) and Lemuel (part VIII), nothing further is known. Parts III and IV are attributed to "the wise." The remaining parts are anonymous
The manner of compilation is conjectural. Parts II and V may have circulated first as independent collections, compiled before the fall of Jerusalem, as the references to Solomon ( Proverb 10:1) and Hezekiah ( Proverb 25:1) suggest. Parts III, IV and VII would seem to belong together as a third collection of a similar kind. The author of the first nine chapters, a religious sage familiar with the earlier sacred books, was the editor of the whole as we have it, probably in the early part of the fifth century B.C
Christ and the Apostles often expressly quoted the Proverbs ( John 7:38; Romans 12:20; James 4:6) or repeated their teaching; compare Luke 10:14, and Proverb 25:7; 1 Peter 4:8; James 5:20 and Proverb 10:12. The book has an important place in the Latin and Greek liturgies
On the basis of titles, subject matter, and poetic structure the Book of Proverbs may be divided as follows
I. Introduction: The Value of Wisdom ( Proverb 1:1- 9:18)
II. First Collection of the Proverbs of Solomon ( Proverb 10:1- 22:16)
III. Sayings of the Wise ( Proverb 22:17- 24:22)
IV. Other Sayings of the Wise ( Proverb 24:23-34)
V. Second Collection of the Proverbs of Solomon ( Proverb 25:1- 29:27)
VI. The Words of Agur ( Proverb 30:1-6)
VII. Numerical Proverbs ( Proverb 30:7-33)

1.verse: Does not Wisdom call, and Understanding raise her voice?

2.verse: On the top of the heights along the road, at the crossroads she takes her stand;

3.verse: By the gates at the approaches of the city, in the entryways she cries aloud:

4.verse: "To you, O men, I call; my appeal is to the children of men.

5.verse: You simple ones, gain resource, you fools, gain sense.

6.verse: "Give heed! for noble things I speak; honesty opens my lips.

7.verse: Yes, the truth my mouth recounts, but the wickedness my lips abhor.

8.verse: Sincere are all the words of my mouth, no one of them is wily or crooked;

9.verse: All of them are plain to the man of intelligence, and right to those who attain knowledge.

10.verse: Receive my instruction in preference to silver, and knowledge rather than choice gold.

11.verse: (For Wisdom is better than corals, and no choice possessions can compare with her.)

12.verse: "I, Wisdom, dwell with experience, and judicious knowledge I attain.

13.verse: (The fear of the LORD is to hate evil;) Pride, arrogance, the evil way, and the perverse mouth I hate.

14.verse: Mine are counsel and advice; Mine is strength; I am understanding.

15.verse: By me kings reign, and lawgivers establish justice;

16.verse: By me princes govern, and nobles; all the rulers of earth.

17.verse: "Those who love me I also love, and those who seek me find me.

18.verse: With me are riches and honor, enduring wealth and prosperity.

19.verse: My fruit is better than gold, yes, than pure gold, and my revenue than choice silver.

20.verse: On the way of duty I walk, along the paths of justice,

21.verse: Granting wealth to those who love me, and filling their treasuries.

22.verse: "The LORD begot me, the first-born of his ways, the forerunner of his prodigies of long ago;

23.verse: From of old I was poured forth, at the first, before the earth.

24.verse: When there were no depths I was brought forth, when there were no fountains or springs of water;

25.verse: Before the mountains were settled into place, before the hills, I was brought forth;

26.verse: While as yet the earth and the fields were not made, nor the first clods of the world.

27.verse: "When he established the heavens I was there, when he marked out the vault over the face of the deep;

28.verse: When he made firm the skies above, when he fixed fast the foundations of the earth;

29.verse: When he set for the sea its limit, so that the waters should not transgress his command;

30.verse: Then was I beside him as his craftsman, and I was his delight day by day, Playing before him all the while,

31.verse: playing on the surface of his earth; and I found delight in the sons of men.

32.verse: "So now, O children, listen to me;

33.verse: instruction and wisdom do not reject! Happy the man who obeys me, and happy those who keep my ways,

34.verse: Happy the man watching daily at my gates, waiting at my doorposts;

35.verse: For he who finds me finds life, and wins favor from the LORD;

36.verse: But he who misses me harms himself; all who hate me love death."

annotations.1: [1-36] Wisdom is here personified as in Proverb 1:20-33, to confirm the words of the teacher of wisdom. She exalts her grandeur and origin, and invites all ( Proverb 8:1-11) to be attentive to her salutary influence in human society ( Proverb 8:12-21), for she was privileged to be present at the creation of the world ( Proverb 8:22-31). Finally, she promises life and the favor of God to those who find her, death to those who despise her.
annotations.2: [5] Simple ones . . . fools: see note on Proverb 1:4
annotations.3: [7-8] The truth and sincerity of wisdom are absolute because they are divine. They can neither deceive nor tolerate deception. An intelligent man understands and accepts them
annotations.4: [14] What is here predicated of wisdom is elsewhere attributed to God ( Job 12:13-16)
annotations.5: [22-31] Wisdom is of divine origin. It is here represented as a being which existed before all things ( Proverb 8:22-26) and concurred with God when he planned and executed the creation of the universe, adorned it with beauty and variety, and established its wonderful order ( Proverb 8:27-30). Here that plurality of divine Persons is foreshadowed which was afterward to be fully revealed when Wisdom in the Person of Jesus Christ became incarnate
annotations.6: [23] Poured forth: the exact meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain; the expression must imply the equivalent of "born." The Hebrews liken the movement of air and of spirit to that of liquids
annotations.7: [24-26] The formless mass from which God created the heavens and the earth; cf Genesis 1:1-2; 2:4-6
annotations.8: [30] His craftsman: furnishing God with the plan, as it were, for the creation of all things; cf Job 38:1-2; Wisdom 7:22- 8:1. I was his delight: the ever-present object of God's complacency

1.verse: A mild answer calms wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.

2.verse: The tongue of the wise pours out knowledge, but the mouth of fools spurts forth folly.

3.verse: The eyes of the LORD are in every place, keeping watch on the evil and the good.

4.verse: A soothing tongue is a tree of life, but a perverse one crushes the spirit.

5.verse: The fool spurns his father's admonition, but prudent is he who heeds reproof.

6.verse: In the house of the just there are ample resources, but the earnings of the wicked are in turmoil.

7.verse: The lips of the wise disseminate knowledge, but the heart of fools is perverted.

8.verse: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to the LORD, but the prayer of the upright is his delight.

9.verse: The way of the wicked is an abomination to the LORD, but he loves the man who pursues virtue.

10.verse: Severe punishment is in store for the man who goes astray; he who hates reproof will die.

11.verse: The nether world and the abyss lie open before the LORD; how much more the hearts of men!

12.verse: The senseless man loves not to be reproved; to wise men he will not go.

13.verse: A glad heart lights up the face, but by mental anguish the spirit is broken.

14.verse: The mind of the intelligent man seeks knowledge, but the mouth of fools feeds on folly.

15.verse: Every day is miserable for the depressed, but a lighthearted man has a continual feast.

16.verse: Better a little with fear of the LORD than a great fortune with anxiety.

17.verse: Better a dish of herbs where love is than a fatted ox and hatred with it.

18.verse: An ill-tempered man stirs up strife, but a patient man allays discord.

19.verse: The way of the sluggard is hemmed in as with thorns, but the path of the diligent is a highway.

20.verse: A wise son makes his father glad, but a fool of a man despises his mother.

21.verse: Folly is joy to the senseless man, but the man of understanding goes the straight way.

22.verse: Plans fail when there is no counsel, but they succeed when counselors are many.

23.verse: There is joy for a man in his utterance; a word in season, how good it is!

24.verse: The path of life leads the prudent man upward, that he may avoid the nether world below.

25.verse: The LORD overturns the house of the proud, but he preserves intact the widow's landmark.

26.verse: The wicked man's schemes are an abomination to the LORD, but the pure speak what is pleasing to him.

27.verse: He who is greedy of gain brings ruin on his own house, but he who hates bribes will live.

28.verse: The just man weighs well his utterance, but the mouth of the wicked pours out evil.

29.verse: The LORD is far from the wicked, but the prayer of the just he hears.

30.verse: A cheerful glance brings joy to the heart; good news invigorates the bones.

31.verse: He who listens to salutary reproof will abide among the wise.

32.verse: He who rejects admonition despises his own soul, but he who heeds reproof gains understanding.

33.verse: The fear of the LORD is training for wisdom, and humility goes before honors.
